content: @WG-async-sprint-planning meeting in ~31 minutes at 2021-09-16T09:00:00-07:00. The agenda is in the doc which should be editable by everyone.
If you have time before the meeting, please update the status of sprint goals in the doc! I copied @eholk and made checkboxes for my items
@WG-async-sprint-planning okay
hey everyone

The agenda for today is

  • Sprint retrospective
  • Assign [polish issues]
  • Identify sprint goals

[polish issues]: https://github.com/orgs/rust-lang/projects/2
Dear me, that went quickly :)
first up
Sprint retrospective
how did the first sprint go?
quickly :)
I feel like I didn't quite feel like we were sprinting
that is, I didn't feel like we had clear defined goals we were working towards
not so much the pace of progress
that said, @tmandry, I feel pretty good about the progress that we made on the evaluation doc (which I literally just pushed 4 minutes ago)
I was going to say that the goals I put down felt a little too big
I think for me I'd have preferred it if we had managed to be very concrete in what we hoped to achieve
^ this, basically
That would also help with getting other people to contribute: smaller more directed action items tend to attract more new contributors
Yes
I do think the 2 week frequency is good
at least until we get better at things
me too
I was going to ask about the frequency
if people like it we can keep it at 2 weeks
If it were shorter there wouldn't be time to get anything done, and if it were longer we'd forget we were sprinting.
right
perfect :)
3 week sprints might work, but that's a weird number
maybe when we have more concrete goals etc we may find sprint meetings are more like a "check-in", and that's ok, we can space them out more then
okay, well I guess that leads us into defining the next sprint
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Do we want to talk about what each of us got done? I think maybe we were supposed to update the doc :)
we can
It seems useful to me
hmm I’m realizing that I might have put some very short-term todo items in the doc, while you really only want goals for the next sprint in there?
I think ideally for the future I'd like for everyone to prepare a short blurb about what they did ahead of the meeting
@pnkfelix hmm, I'd say short-term todo items can be sprint goals
ah, you know, I hadn't scrolled all the way down in the hackmd
I was getting distracted by the template :)
okay. When/if you see them, you might see what I mean. :)
or, I guess, I was distracted by the empty 2021-09-16 and hadn't seen the upates in 2021-09-02
oh, I misread the doc structure
I think those goals under tooling look fine
they're well-defined, at least
Is the intention that unfinished and still needed goals will be copied upward into the next sprint’s outline?
yeah
we'll explicitly have time for that later in the meeting

anyway, the only thing I wanted to say was that @tmandry and I spent some time talking over the "async fn in traits" design space, and we've been expanding the async-fundamentals-initiative repository. In particular, I (just) pushed a summary of our discussions to the evaluation page, which I thought might be useful as a "template in progress" for others who feel a bit stuck. I'd also love to have discussions with people (outside the meeting) about the bounding futures challenge and the two ideas we've discussed thus far for solving it, neither of which I think are really right.
(yes, let's do "show and tell" if people have stuff they want to share)
right now?
I think so :)
yes
I’ll just say that I’m happy with the amount of excitement about the console. The Tokio developers are doing a good job of trying to enlist outside contributions.
@Gus Wynn got a good chunk of #[must_not_suspend] implemented and out for review (#88865)

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88865 is basically done (well, at least the basic analysis version, it can definitely be extended, for example supporting the attribute on fn return value's, like the rfc suggested). Oli's recent comments are more examples of more complex analysis we could do
that's awesome!
I made some progress in tracking temporaries in the generator liveness pass, but it's going a lot more slowly than I'd hoped
(the last two weeks had a surprising amount of non-Rust stuff come up too which distracted me somewhat)

Gus Wynn said:

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88865 is basically done (well, at least the basic analysis version, it can definitely be extended, for example supporting the attribute on fn return value's, like the rfc suggested). Oli's recent comments are more examples of more complex analysis we could do

again, its the most basic version of the lint possible, but it will pretty much cover the main usecases I can think of (@eholk 's work on generator analysis will help too. For example, calling drop on a must_not_suspend value before and await doesn't actually remove it from the types that are considered held, but moving it into a scope does ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I made some progress on the T-lang stable iterator item proposal (based off the T-lang meeting feedback), but haven't published it yet.
On the other hand, I've seen a bunch of inquiries about stable Generators, so I think I'll write a (personal) blog post outlining what I think we should do to gauge community reaction.
@Gus Wynn that's great! I like focusing on an MVP

tmandry said:

Gus Wynn that's great! I like focusing on an MVP

there are FIXME's for everything else
okay, cool

tmandry said:

I think ideally for the future I'd like for everyone to prepare a short blurb about what they did ahead of the meeting

it may be worth reserving the first 10 minutes of the meeting for people to write updates
but we can discuss that out of band
I've just found that "homework" tends to be hard to achieve :)
(that is, write updates in the doc)
yeah, that makes sense
The other thing we should do in this section is identify blockers or things that people in this room might be able to help with
I don't know if anyone has anything on that today

if not, I think we can move on?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
I'm waiting to hear from the Lang team on my doc updates for liveness generator captures. I'm assuming they just pick it up at their next meeting?
One thing I will say: I was trying to use the Rustacean Principles to analyze the various options and it was quite interesting. It was helpful, but also suggested there are more tweaks required. :)
I'd be interested in working with others on doing the same to their designs

eholk said:

I'm waiting to hear from the Lang team on my doc updates for liveness generator captures. I'm assuming they just pick it up at their next meeting?

sounds right -- we usually schedule those meetings at the start of the month, we could potentially schedule something for last week in september, if I recall that was available
anyway, let's check in on that out of band
@eholk not sure if you were expecting feedback this week; RustConf pre-empted this weeks’ lang team meeting
Yeah, that's what I figured
It's my first time doing this, so I'm not sure the timeline. It's not a blocker for me yet though
(or maybe it will need to wait for a separate design meeting, if I’m reading nikos’ response correctly.)
anyway like niko said, we can resolve out-of-band
Sounds good
okay

Polish issues

the next thing I wanted to do was look at polish issues
since we decided to pick one of these up for each sprint
great
There are a few suggestions in the project board
I optimistically put some in "In Progress" for the last sprint, but I think those are good options to pick up as well.
I will admit I don’t know where to look on the board
https://github.com/orgs/rust-lang/projects/2
There's also the query for all the open async bugs: https://github.com/search?q=org%3Arust-lang+is%3Aissue+label%3AA-async-await+is%3Aopen&type=Issues

Esteban Küber said:

https://github.com/orgs/rust-lang/projects/2

(i meant where to go within that. Or are all of these polish?)
In theory these are all polish now
I think we're interpreting polish pretty broadly though, and some could probably be pruned as not polish too
Oh, I think I see. the description mentions that most are polish, but I didn’t see it in the title so I was confused as to scope of this project board.
omg, if someone smarter than me picked up https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/63033, that would be amazing, at work thats the one people hit the most
I can try to pick that up
not to say I am smarter than you :P
just seems in my purview
oh that does look like it could be a good mentorship one, maybe
yeah, I was thinking I'd try to mentor someone
I have some notes on it
diagnosing the cause
So is the “On Deck” section things that would be good to claim?
yeah
My thinking was On Deck is "this is a good thing to work on"

Re-land "add IntoFuture trait and support for await" #67982

is at the top of the list, but I'm not sure if I consider it polish anymore
Then we move the ones we picked into "In Progress (current sprint)"
I am going to avoid picking up a new one till https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88865 is landed, I have a good amount of other life stuff going on
And then at the end of the sprint we move everything from In Progress either to Done or back to On Deck
I'll take a look at #74256
I have poked a little bit at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/72312, but haven't solved it yet.
In theory it should be fixed, since NLL is on now, but it seems like the nll feature does something else still. I want to figure out what that is.
But I hope to do so within this sprint
I might be willing to poke at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/72956
I can take a look at #72117

That just made me think... We should have a battery of tests of sync and async functions doing the exact same thing: they should look and behave the same, and if they don't it's a polish bug, but at least it's tracked in repo.
and maybe #60658, but I want to focus on getting a quick win first :)

Esteban Küber said:

That just made me think... We should have a battery of tests of sync and async functions doing the exact same thing: they should look and behave the same, and if they don't it's a polish bug, but at least it's tracked in repo.

hmm I wonder if fuzzing would be nice : )

Gus Wynn said:

I am going to avoid picking up a new one till https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88865 is landed, I have a good amount of other life stuff going on

if I finish that early, I may begin to poke around: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/77175 (i think ive seen people at work hit this too)

Esteban Küber said:

That just made me think... We should have a battery of tests of sync and async functions doing the exact same thing: they should look and behave the same, and if they don't it's a polish bug, but at least it's tracked in repo.

that's an interesting idea. I like it
I would consider that polish work
agreed
okay, does everyone have an issue they're going to be working on?
That's probably worth making a new Polish initiative for
(the connection to fuzzing sounds tenuous, given the constraints one must meet to actually turn a fn into an async fn, w.r.t. its callers…)

eholk said:

That's probably worth making a new Polish initiative for

agreed

pnkfelix said:

(the connection to fuzzing sounds tenuous, given the constraints one must meet to actually turn a fn into an async fn, w.r.t. its callers…)

yeah, I was just imagining a tool that generates new programs, and makes a sync/async variant.
not sure if it's a good idea
Ah, not something that converts existing programs
test program generation is something that has been on my mind lately, what with the anon union parsing bug
I bet we could maybe get people re-excited about the wg-grammar group if we used the grammar for test generation...
sorry I’m going off the rails
Let's add these issues under the "Polish" section in the doc
and then move on to the next section :)
remember to put names by each item
okay
Sprint goals
of course we just identified the first ones
let's focus in our respective areas now
sounds good, shall we edit the doc for a few moments?
yes, let's take a few minutes to do that
just to be clear, becasue I’m new to this group: The sprint under discussion is a week long? And it starts on which day?
2 weeks
2 weeks
/me will need to add a “jinx” emoji to Zulip
the meeting is the start and end point of each sprint
so @tmandry I want to put something specific-ish
I'm trying to decide what that is :)
I think we're going to continue on the Evaluation Doc
I feel like we should be focusing on "static async fn in traits" and identifying a kind of "MVP" we are going to work towards
from an organizational perspective it seems like we still need the initiative and charter written?
yes, I guess, we should copy that over, but it also seems fairly easy
if it's not, we're working too hard :P
I feel like the charter is partly there
Oh that reminds me: everyone please add making goal / initiative issues to the list, if you haven't already
How do you feel about a goal of "Identify first MVP", @tmandry?
As in a minimal lang feature we can go implement and experiment with?
that does sound like a good goal

tmandry said:

Oh that reminds me: everyone please add making goal / initiative issues to the list, if you haven't already

These each have checklists of their own.. as a starting point for a sprint goal, I might suggest "open an issue and complete half the items" or something
I'm not sure I know what you mean by that :)
I'm referring to the issue templates for goals and initiatives
(I already made one for async fn everywhere and async fundamentals)
example https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-async-foundations/issues/242
this is just sort of "organizational table stakes"
in my opinion
ok ok
but I also want to leave some flexibility instead of asking everyone to check off all boxes before doing anything else
okay, I'm not seeing more activity in the doc
I think we've reached quiescence
yes
let's go through them then

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Prepare a lang-team proposal for "async fn in traits" – tmandry
  • [ ] Write up a charter for "async fn fundamentals" – tmandry [+ nikomatsakis]
  • [ ] Identify MVP language feature for "async fn in traits" along with all major unknowns that must be resolved before it can move forward
..not much else to say, I guess

Async iteration

  • [ ] T-lang proposal for async iteration item - estebank
  • [ ] Update wg-async-foundations repo to link to async-iteration repo - estebank
  • [ ] blogpost outlining the effort - estebank
sounds good
estebank, the blog post:
are you thinking sort of like "identifying the top-level goals and sketching an MVP"?
I guess we can talk offline about it, I'm just curious, it sounds like it might be made more specific as a goal
@Esteban Küber sounds like you have an initiative repo but can you also fill out the goal/initiative issue templates?
where is blog post targetted? inside-rust blog?
or personal blog?
I guess it doesn’t matter too much
I was thinking personal, but can do it in inside rust
the objective is more of a "rally the troops" than "this is the design"
I think either is fine
I agree that either is ok
personal might be preferred actually, if it's just getting eyes on preliminary notes
(irlo also works for that)
okay, moving along

Polish

Initiatives:

  • [ ] (eholk) Set up initiative for testing that sync and async programs have the same behavior
  • [ ] (eholk) Discuss liveness-based generator captures with lang-team
  • [ ] (eholk) Generator liveness analysis: correctly handle temporary values
  • [ ] (eholk) Fill out landing pages for polish initiatives

Polish issues:

  • [ ] #[must_not_suspend]: basic cases implemented, awaiting final review: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88865
  • [ ] (tmandry) confusing diagnostic for incorrect type parameter on BoxFuture #72117
  • [ ] (eholk) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74256
  • [ ] (estebank) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/72312
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/72956
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/63033
I guess titles are nice
I can go back and add them
(I wonder if we could get Zulip to do something nice for the popups here)
Zulip auto-links issue numbers at least
ok, we're running out of time

Tooling

  • [ ] make goal/initiative issues - pnkfelix
  • [ ] Add entry for (tokio-)console to Tooling roadmap in async vision doc - pnkfelix
  • [ ] Post console-subscriber into crates.io (preview version, at least) - pnkfelix
  • [ ] create repo for crashdump debugging initiative - mw
that first item
is just because you told us all to put it in
yeah :) I hope it's helpful and not just busy-work
I’ll let you know in 2 weeks.
it shouldn't take much time at least
okay, cool
we're at time
gotta run, but thanks everyone!
see you in 2 weeks
